Row.Text: Information Era recon and ranged unit. Price shown is how much it costs to hire this unit for 20 turns.

The Predator Drone is a late game hovering unit. It can move around the map like helicopters. It can perform ranged attacks within its range of 2 tiles. The Predator Drone provides great flexibility to military operations, quickly responding to crises around the world.

The Predator Drone is an Information Era Fighter unit, available when the civilization discovers Telecommunications. The Contracting Agency is required for this unit to be built. The Predator Drone becomes obsolete on the discovery of Nanotechnology.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE] The General Atomics MQ-1 Predator is an American remotely piloted aircraft built by General Atomics and used primarily by the United States Air Force and Central Intelligence Agency. Initially conceived in the early 1990s for aerial reconnaissance and forward observation roles, the Predator carries cameras and other sensors but has been modified and upgraded to carry and fire two AGM-114 Hellfire missiles or other munitions. The aircraft, in use since 1995, has seen combat in war in Afghanistan, Pakistan, the NATO intervention in Bosnia, Serbia, Iraq War, Yemen, Libyan civil war, the intervention in Syria, and Somalia.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]The USAF describes the Predator as a 'Tier II' MALE UAS, for medium-altitude, long-endurance unmanned aircraft system. The UAS consists of four aircraft or 'air vehicles' with sensors, a ground control station, and a primary satellite link communication suite Powered by a Rotax engine and driven by a propeller, the air vehicle can fly up to 460 miles to a target, loiter overhead for 14 hours, then return to its base.[NEWLINE][NEWLINE]Following 2001, the RQ-1 Predator became the primary remotely piloted aircraft used for offensive operations by the USAF and the CIA in Afghanistan and the Pakistani tribal areas; it has also been deployed elsewhere. Because offensive uses of the Predator are classified by the US, U.S. military officials have reported an appreciation for the intelligence and reconnaissance-gathering abilities of RPAs but declined to publicly discuss their offensive use.
